--- title: Changing the Default `ggplot` theme author: Robert W. Walker date: '2023-01-25' slug: visualize-two-qualities categories: - R - dataviz - ggplot2 tags: - plot subtitle: '' summary: '' lastmod: '2023-01-25T08:04:06-07:00' toc: true image: "img/preview.png" --- One can globally set the theme in an RMarkdown or Quarto Markdown document with `theme_set()`. If run at the console, every subsequent `ggplot` invocation will default to that theme. If set inside an R/Qmd file, then it will apply to everything in the file. First, let me load ggplot. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ## The `cars` data I will use R's internal cars dataset to illustrate. `?cars` will detail the variables. ![cars description](img/cars.png) This is the data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(DT) datatable(cars) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## A plot with defaults ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(cars) + aes(x=speed, y=dist) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Setting a default theme Let me set the theme for this to `theme_minimal`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} theme_set(theme_minimal()) ``` ::: ## The Same Plot with a New Default Theme ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(cars) + aes(x=speed, y=dist) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Implications This is the primary way that one might **brand** the use of ggplot in documents. There is a common mantra that says, if you write the same code more than twice, it is probably best redone as a function. I have done this in a gist. To be continued...
